events.target_title: Don't ask to "Select Audio Device" every time an audio device is plugged in

note.body:
Most users probably have a standard set of headphones that they plug in, so perhaps a dconf setting could be added for the default choice.

```
if no_setting:
  show_dialog()
else: 
  choose_setting(dconf.get('gnome.org.sound.default_headphone_device'))
```

Specs
```
Dell XPS13 Developer Edition
Ubuntu 18.04
GNOME 3.28.3

Output of lshw
        *-multimedia
             description: Audio device
             product: Intel Corporation
             vendor: Intel Corporation
             physical id: 1f.3
             bus info: pci@0000:00:1f.3
             version: 21
             width: 64 bits
             clock: 33MHz
             capabilities: pm msi bus_master cap_list
             configuration: driver=snd_hda_intel latency=32
             resources: irq:125 memory:dc428000-dc42bfff memory:dc400000-dc40ffff
```

**Risks**

- Given a sound card without impedance sensing, if a user sets the default to *Headphones*, but plugs a microphone in and plays audio, the microphone could be damaged by incoming audio signals

**Acceptance Criteria**

- Add dconf setting (path to be determined)
- Connecting a device to the headphone/microphone port automatically selects the corresponding setting based on the dconf key
- Connecting a device to the port prompts the user for their selection if no setting value is set
- Reply to several of the AskUbuntu StackExchange threads that mention this topic with a proposed solution

I'm a developer, but not super familiar with the GNOME stack, but if someone could point me in the right direction I could take a stab at adding a setting and tying it in to that dialog.

events.target_title: Don't ask to "Select Audio Device" every time an audio device is plugged in

note.body:
@bberg Good points.

> 1. Should we warn about microphones possibly being damaged? If yes, how?

Do we know if this is *actually* a problem?  There seems to be uncertainty if this is true.  Perhaps spike out whether there is a real risk and a profile on what that looks like? 

> 1. It needs to be easy to reset the default choice in gnome-control-center.

:thumbsup: Given a two-phase approach, I think this would be part of the Phase 2 where a checkbox is added to the dialog.

Phase 1 -> Add a setting, let users change via dconf-editor (The Description field on the setting could include a warning about microphone damage)
Phase 2 -> Add a checkbox to the selection dialog, also add a setting to gnome-control-centre

**Questions**

1. What was the behaviour on older versions of GNOME?  @carlosg mentions that the dialog was added after jack sensing was in place, does this mean that the dialog & the jack sensing is new?
2. Do we know if this *only* impacts hardware that a) lacks jack impedance sensing or b) drivers that lack the detection?

events.target_title: Don't ask to "Select Audio Device" every time an audio device is plugged in

note.body:
> No, and I suspect that any "proper" microphone has reasonable protections in place. Basically, it is impossible to know if there is (a relevant amount of) cheap hardware around that might break … 

Haha, that is a bit of a problem.  Perhaps this is similar to "premature optimization" in development, and we're just making up a problem that might not exist.  I wonder if there are documented cases of microphones being damaged by playing audio over them.

> Fair enough, I guess just having an option hidden somewhere to disable (and enable) the dialog would work.

I was thinking that the dconf setting would be "*Default Audio Jack Mode*" rather than "*Disable Device Selection Dialog*".  Once the option was set, it could be cleared to re-enable the dialog, changed in the Sound Settings panel.

The user wants to plug their device in to the port and have it automatically behave as they expect, so they should be able to set a default mode instead of just disabling the dialog.  

> 1. We didn't do anything; not sure what default this results in

:thumbsup: 

> 1. Yes, hardware with working sensing is not affected. And indeed, you will never see the dialog on e.g. a ThinkPad.

It's unfortunate that the Dell XPS13 Developer Edition with pre-installed Ubuntu has hardware (or a driver) that lacks sensing.  From a GNOME-credibility perspective it would be nice to solve this out of the box for people buying the only big-brand Linux-by-default laptop.

events.target_title: Inaccurate Eyedropper/Color Picker
Inaccurate Eyedropper/Color Picker

note.body:
Example: I have a project with two layers, Layer 1 is below Layer 2. Layer 1 is just transparent, Layer 2 has a square in it with the hex color "1f1f1f". I want to fill Layer 1 with that color so that it matches Layer 2. To do that I open the foreground color selection dialog and click the eyedropper, with Layer 1 still selected I click on the color I want but instead of getting "1f1f1f" I get "212020" which is very similar but not exact.
To get the correct color, what I have to do is first select Layer 2 then open the foreground color selection dialog and click the eyedropper or use the Color Picker Tool, then I click the color I want and I get the correct one "1f1f1f". Then I select Layer 1 and use the Bucket Fill Tool to fill in the layer.

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

note.body:
I've done my best to read this thread and the code committed above, but would still benefit from some "instructions to mail server providers". Could this change include a documentation change somewhere too, please?

My conclusions/questions from reading the above are:
* You have chosen to implement the TB autoconfig format, so there should be improvements to the accuracy of auto-configuration information
* You have chosen not to send the email address of the user who requires their configuration data, so I cannot give them full autoconfig data
* The code committed doesn't include any handling of the placeholders such as %EMAILLOCALPART% so I can't rely on that for my users to be able to infer the correct username
* Thus is there any mechanism for me to be able to give the correct data to each user?
* I've implemented SRV records and Outlook's Autodiscover as well. I'm not sure what order of precedence these methods might take in Evolution's autoconfig process, or whether any of the data from each might be merged.

Thank you for your guidance.

events.target_title: Extend Mail autoconfig to check in server's autoconfiguration too

I think some of the information you have provided has value. For example - does it actually say in the Evolution documentation that the Thunderbird config style is what is used, and here is a link to thedocumentation for that?

note.body: Thanks for the response. I haven't used KDE in ages, but I installed it now. Now in KDE I can get compositing to turn off in fullscreen (FLIP and VSYNC is enabled; Alt-Shift-F12 shifts between BLIT and FLIP), but as soon as I turn on G-sync in a game the screen turns black and stays that way. So it is worse than in Gnome.

events.target_title: Screen blanking causing signal loss with G-sync

note.body:
In LXDE, G-sync works fine. I can't repeat the same behavior there, because its lockscreen doesn't cause the screen to turn off. When locking the screen in LXDE (with "no screensaver" is specified in settings), the screen just remains blank and signal doesn't appear to be turned off. 

There is entirely different behavior in Gnome. When locking the screen in Gnome, screen goes black and the display shows Displayport logo in upper corner (like it has just detected a signal). After a few seconds it turns the logo off, then on again (like it detected a signal again). After a while staying black, power led on the display goes blinking blue and display now seems in some kind of suspend (even though every power saving feature is turned off; both in Gnome and in the display itself). Sometimes the screen flashes half green for a moment before entering this state. So there is something weird going on in Gnome lockscreen. When logging in again, now G-sync is broken and needs a reboot to work or the aforementioned refresh rate toggling.

$ sudo chmod -v 4711 cdrdao  
$ sudo chmod -v 4711 wodim  
$ sudo chmod -v 0755 growisofs

events.target_title: GitgExt introspection hardcodes build-time libgitg-ext.so library path
Potential vulnerability: gpg key trust extrapolation to new UIDs
Potential vulnerability: gpg key trust extrapolation to new UIDs

note.body:
No, `--status-fd` doesn't include the necessary data.  I think the 'simplest' way of implementing this currently would be to `gpg --with-colons --list-key <key-id>`, and then parse trust for individual UIDs.  However, it's unclear to me what to do next, UI-wise.

One option would be to replace the displayed UID with one with better trust, if such is present on the key.  Another option would be to go for full sender verification, and explicitly compare the address in 'From:' with the UIDs on the key.  This would also imply explicitly warning when 'From:' doesn't match any trusted UIDs on the key.

Could you explain to me the significance of closing the bug?  Do you consider the issue non-significant enough to warrant making the report public?

events.target_title: Custom skins for some game, created with third-party GIMP plugin "DDS", crash that game when using GIMP 2.10.6 to create them

note.body:
I have the same problem with World of Warships textures, but there is more than one problem because they changed how textures are handled.

Prior there was a 4096x4096 .dds texture with mipmap (and it also worked without them) but to speed up texture rendering there is now a 512x512 .dds file with mipmaps, a 4096x4096 .dd0, 2048x2048 .dd1 and 1024x1024.dd1 file.

They also use a different kind of compression now as the .dd0 file is ~10MB and the .dds file ~200kB while prior it was 60-100MB

As soon as you open and save the .dds with gimp, size increase to 1MB and the game crashes 
while Gimp can open all those other files, you only save as .dds, however renaming it to .dd0/1/2 may work but cannot be tested as the game crashes anyway

while changing file size in the past did not had any effect (custom HD textures instead of regular sized in game ones) this may be the reason as the graphic options changed too

note.body:
I think I hit this too. I don't have many notifications, but I got a 1-second freeze every time a tooltip or context menu _disappeared_.

After an embarrassing amount of investigation I have uncovered that the delay came from my `.bashrc`. (Anaconda's `conda init` block in particular.) I fixed that and the freezes are immediately gone.

I don't know why `.bashrc` would get executed every time a tooltip disappears. I thought I'd mention this in case someone else has the same root cause for the freezes.

P.S.: I've reverted `.bashrc` just to check and the freezes did not come back. I'm no longer sure of anything.

events.target_title: Roadmap shows GTK+3, why not GTK+4?
No waveform for some videoclips

note.body:
For me the problem is that many of my video clips have very low sound volume (which is what I need; I change volume with Audacity only after rendering, together with applying tricky effects).

How about just scaling the waveform up to the maximum value? This solves the issue for me.

```patch
--- /var/lib/flatpak/app/org.pitivi.Pitivi/x86_64/stable.orig/active/files/lib/pitivi/python/pitivi/timeline/previewers.py    1970-01-01 03:00:00.000000000 +0300
+++ /var/lib/flatpak/app/org.pitivi.Pitivi/x86_64/stable/active/files/lib/pitivi/python/pitivi/timeline/previewers.py   2019-01-10 05:25:37.147414018 +0300
@@ -1001,7 +1001,11 @@

         if os.path.exists(filename):
             with open(filename, "rb") as samples:
-                self.samples = list(numpy.load(samples))
+                samples_array = numpy.load(samples)
+                max_value = samples_array.max()
+                if max_value > 0.0001:
+                    samples_array *= 100.0 / max_value
+                self.samples = list(samples_array)
             self._startRendering()
         else:
             self.wavefile = filename
```

events.target_title: touchpad vertical scroll causes horizontal scrolling of timeline

note.body:
To me, as an active touchpad user, it turns out the timeline scrolling is not only unintuitive but just **unusable**: just little scrolling event produces a massive scrolling away.

Also, I'm using real physical clicks on touchpad, rather than touch as click. Moving a pressed finger is uncomfortable (as it becomes easy to release it too quickly); so during dragging a clip I usually use both fingers: one to actually make a press and the other to drag the clip on timeline. Usually I release both fingers at the same time and that produces an unwanted scroll (which is also very massive).

After applying this change both issues disappear to me:
- the scrolling in all directions is similar to web browsers' behavior
- and no more massive scrolling is happening

```patch
--- /var/lib/flatpak/app/org.pitivi.Pitivi/x86_64/stable.orig/active/files/lib/pitivi/python/pitivi/timeline/timeline.py      1970-01-01 03:00:00.000000000 +0300
+++ /var/lib/flatpak/app/org.pitivi.Pitivi/x86_64/stable/active/files/lib/pitivi/python/pitivi/timeline/timeline.py     2019-01-09 06:30:09.987994699 +0300
@@ -595,12 +595,8 @@
             x, unused_y = event_widget.translate_coordinates(self.layout, event.x, event.y)
             self.hadj.set_value(self.nsToPixel(position) - x)
         else:
-            if delta_y > 0:
-                # Scroll right.
-                self.__scroll_adjustment(self.hadj, 1)
-            else:
-                # Scroll left.
-                self.__scroll_adjustment(self.hadj, -1)
+            self.__scroll_adjustment(self.hadj, delta_x)
+            self.__scroll_adjustment(self.vadj, delta_y)

         return False
```

Can we have at least an option in settings for touchpad users so they could have a usable and intuitive behavior? Thanks.

Waveform is almost invisible for videos with low sound volume

note.body:
> We have to take care to scale all the waveforms exactly the same

Do you mean for all clips on a timeline, so user could distinguish clips with low and high volume?

It's not only harder to implement efficiently; for me it would still be problematic to use, because as soon as I add a clip with very high volume—I will stop seeing all other waveforms.

Maybe we could think about meta question: what's the **purpose** of these waveforms? I personally use them to carefully cut clips in parts for my vlog, to make these [jump cuts](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QHhVnIyO_NQ&t=20s) things which are popular nowadays. And this is where waveforms are handy: it's easier to make cuts very precisely and quickly, because the silences are visually visible on timeline

During modifying my clips I sometimes add other clips, recorded by somebody else, with other hardware, where sound is usually amplified. And in case if all waveforms may suddenly change their size after adding some clip—for me personally it would be a disaster :) I would need to select clips strategically, rather than creatively.

Thanks!

This forcing could be done by CSS and can ruin user defined fonts or diferent OS settings in a program. So please find a way to rollback Cantarell or change default font for GTK < 4 apps to other font.

Thanks in advance, is a very problematic bug in the terms of UX experience. Please don't ignore it and provide a fix backward GTK version compatible.

I have `3.24.1-2`, and don't find a way to fix it, as far I know is a `CSS` setting to set `tnums` but my GTK Inspector tell is invalid CSS setting (`font-variant-numeric: tabular-nums`). @matthiasc could you explain how please?

I think is a problem of `Cantarell` font, they need to know are more than a font, are the default font for users in multiple OS and they run apps with different versions of `GTK+` in the same system. 

Use of tabular digits font as default is the standard for apps everywere to avoid widgets unecessary "vibrations" and improve better read on fast change in, for example, status bars. If `Cantarell` don't have it by default, break 80-100% of apps in all OS that use it -I think all OS/users that not change the `Gnome` default font-.

events.target_title: negative time shift not work
Focus moves to 'Always on top' window after closing a window, instead of last focused window.

note.body:
I've been looking into this issue, and have determined that the root cause is that in order to focus a 'default' window, the workspace window stack is rebuilt in display order and this order is assumed to be the same as the focus order.


This implicitly puts always-on-top windows first, and results in them being selected. The workspace stack is rebuilt even when not required, so even closing a dialog results in this incorrect behaviour.


My suggestions for ways to fix this bug are

* Keep a last_focused time per window, as is currently kept per display, use this as the sort key for window stacks (for default focus)
* Abandon the concept of rebuilding or reordering a stack. In theory with a synchronous framework this wouldn't be required, but I believe the nature of X may make this infeasible.

I would appreciate comment from a Mutter team member as to which approach is preferred. I will then try and implement it.

note.body:
I just wanted to add a word of encouragement for supporting xdg-decoration. We _need_ this with the SDL project, as we expect to target any desktop environment with a single build, and have no way to make our decorations match the runtime environment. We would want it to look like a KDE app on KDE and a Gnome app on Gnome, but we operate below the GTK+ and Qt software layers.

We can add a simple title bar ourselves as a better-than-nothing fallback, but we would _definitely_ prefer it look like (and, equally important: act like) the rest of the user's running applications.

I see xdg-decoration as a best-of-both-worlds system: Gnome apps can do client-side decorations cleanly, with all the benefits that entails, but this protocol also enables the system to be a gracious host for visiting apps that aren't otherwise part of the Gnome neighborhood...and vice-versa for KDE hosting visiting Gnome apps, and nomadic programs like SDL-based games.

And we all want to be gracious hosts, right?   :)

--ryan.

note.body: @david2 we started with the non-standard KDE protocol because it’ll catch older installs in the future. We’ll definitely support the xdg-decoration standard and keep the KDE-only protocol as a legacy fallback!   :)

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
For what it is worth, I wouldn't be against a library that helps out on the client side, if it hands me back subsurfaces and tells me where to attach them to my window.

I imagine it is not a trivial piece of work to split this code out of GTK+ and divorce it from the GTK+ event loop, since drawing decorations is one thing, but they still need to respond to clicks and drags appropriately, too. Getting the API right on this hypothetical new library could be challenging.

But if it _has_ to be client-side, I'm okay with that. But to be clear, this isn't a question of "we demand SSD because we don't want to deal with it,"--which isn't an unreasonable attitude either, btw--but "we _need_ SSD because we have no avenue to make our apps fit in."

If there's a client-side solution, I'll take it. But right now, short of using GTK+ directly, there isn't a client _or_ server side option to make SDL apps not look alien next to the word processor and email client on the same screen.

If this is something worth exploring, please let me know and I'll open a new issue elsewhere and let this discussion drift away. I would like everyone to be happy with a final outcome, and this seems like one possible way to get to there.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
> The idea is that it takes in a surface and either decorates it with a SSD xdg-shell or, if that's unavailable, creates a GTK+ window with a titlebar, makes the surface a subsurface, creates a thread that runs the GTK+ loop, and passes all events to callbacks via the xdg-shell interface.

How feasible is this to do? If we can make it work, I'd be down for it (and we should probably move the discussion elsewhere if we decide to tackle this). It would solve my worries about trying to separate this code out of GTK+ if it can really just run independently, including its own event loop.

note.body:
I support xdg-decorations for [winit](https://github.com/tomaka/winit). Right now, winit has to work around this by drawing its own title bars using [sctk](https://github.com/Smithay/client-toolkit). It draws its own window decorations, which of course, look like crap, because they're only supposed to be a fallback, not the actual solution:

![image](/uploads/78a7cce3274f44b4ac830280297a45d5/image.png)

No, this is not image manipulation, that's what the actual decorations look like. This is what you want, right? Every application now has to invent its own, shitty version of titlebars, instead of using the platform native ones. Of course this can be "fixed" by converting everything to the Gnome(tm) platform with Gnome(tm) approved libraries.

GTK isn't the only windowing framework out there, that's the problem that Gnome developers don't seem to understand. The only way that other applications could be "fixed to fit your vision" is by using Gnome libraries, because you can't expect other toolkits to bend over backwards to re-implement theming, styling, drawing, etc just to please one single DE. A windowing toolkit like GLFW or SDL or winit should not implement drawing routines. It hasn't been that case for the last 20 years and it won't be for the next 20 years.

> If individual applications rely on non-standard behavior from compositors, those applications should get fixed.

So drawing buttons and a title bar so that people can resize their windows like they have for the past 20 years is now suddenly "non-standard behaviour"!? And you expect every other toolkit to implement a CSS parser to adjust to Gnomes look'n'feel, drawing routines to draw the title as well as constantly be on top of Gnomes styling API - just so that their applications can look good on mutter? Seriously?

> Sure, that's a use case, but it's also kinda silly.

Silly - how is that silly? "I want a window that I can maximize and close graphically" is silly and not Gnomes "vision"? I'm sorry, but something is wrong with your vision then. **CSD vs SSD is a completely separate issue.** xdg-decorations is about whether you draw title bars or not. Sure Gnome wants everyone to use Gnome libraries except Gnomes libraries are so poor in terms of platform / OpenGL support that other frameworks with other goals have to exist.

I will not use Gnome libraries for my GUI framework [azul](https://azul.rs/). And if it then looks bad on mutter - so be it, I'll happily redirect users to this issue and tell them that it was Gnomes decision not to implement it. Then you can have fun with complaints from users. It's not the job of the drawing / GUI toolkit to draw titlebars. I won't re-implement styling and code DE-specific hacks just to please one single compositor.

It breaks separation of concerns, it makes life harder for both users and developers and it's against the Unix philosophy of having one tool doing one thing well (in this case the window library manages windows and the desktop compositor draws and decorates windows, not the other way around). There was not even a technical reason given in this whole discussion other than "we don't want it, suck it". And as a developer - I do not support such blatantly ignorant behaviour.

events.target_title: Provide file format specification?
Provide file format specification?

note.body:
Thanks for the answer. No, I only need read access - I suspected that there was no format specification, but still wanted to ask. I wanted to avoid GNOME libraries in order to be able to read the GSettings (which contain important information such as HiDPI factors and theme colors) in proprietary, statically linked applications. GPL only allows me to dynamically link them, which often leads to dependency / packaging issues in various distros and since (at least from the size of the source code), GVDB is not a huge effort to parse, I wanted to ask if there was a spec. So this way I can put my parser into a statically linked program, since MIT allows it (without publishing my source code).

Thanks for the answer and merry christmas.

events.target_title: Tags and comments use ASCII character set instead of UTF-8
Add an option to edit the tag-list (library) within gThumb (feature-request)
Allow arbitrary OpenVPN options
Restore clipboard contents after unlocking
Gimp closes with multiple Inputs
Please restore the ability to edit a hidden layer
XDG-Decoration support

note.body: Since XDG-Decorations is now part of Wayland protocols, the argument of "that's not the way to do it" is not really valid. XDG-Decorations is in practice a portable way for libraries like SDL, GLFW and the like to handle decorations. This ticket is not about merits or deficiencies or either SSD or CSD. It's about what can be done to fix current messed up situation. One practical proposal is to support XDG-Decorations in Mutter. What's the other?

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
> Fix the applications and libraries that claim the support Wayland, but don't do it properly.

That's not a practical suggestion, that's dismissing the problem, which is not helping. Besides the fact that they are supporting it properly already.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
> a compositor implementation that always uses a mode of `client_side` in configure events would be perfectly spec-compliant.

But it will leave a mess. While it can avoid it. The reason not to avoid it is what exactly for Mutter? For me it sound like *"we just don't want to, go take care of every possible client side decoration case yourself in order to fit each DE better, vs Mutter taking care of one case for every user of SSD".* That is dismissive and not helpful at all.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
> provide decorations that fit your application

That means "we only support consistency use case within one application". What if application itself wants to prefer consistency within the DE? You are preventing relatively easy access to such use case, by requiring such application to provide consistency focused CSD support for each DE. Compositor supporting SSD provides an option for such application to avoid all this multiplication of effort.

So not supporting XDG-Decoration looks more like strongarming avoiding consistency within the DE approach, by shifting that multiplication cost to application developers.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
I'd argue the opposite, that decorations are the primary part part of DE integration consistency. Internal parts are already secondary. Which is especially relevant to examples like above, which might not have any desktop UI elements inside to begin with (think of a game running in SDL window). But decorations are universally implicitly useful.

So suggestion to use the same as rest of the DE goes back to the dependency multiplication problem of "support it for each possible DE yourself". That puts burden on the application to depend on all the related toolkits. It doesn't sound practical to me, to require something like SDL to be dependent on that. Again, it's one feature in the compositor (SSD) vs multiple (as many as there are DEs not supporting SSD) dependencies in each such application. I see no argument so far why compositors can't be helpful with that.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
> So it looks widely different from everything else in the desktop. That's fine

Whether it's fine should be up to developers of the applications to decide. You want to decide it for them, by limiting the options (the alternative is that dependency multiplication like I explained above). That's the essence of the problem I think.

It's ironical, that while the idea of CSD is in theory to leave up to applications to decide how to fit, in this case not providing SSD limits that choice for them. To be consistent with the above idea, both CSD and SSD should be available in the compositor IMHO.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
> "Do whatever you want in your app, but we'll than stick our own stuff around it as _we_ see fit" sounds much more like a contradiction.

*"We'll stick it around if you ask us"* fits well with *"do what you want"*. But *"we won't stick it around even if you ask us"* already doesn't.

events.target_title: XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
Unified decorations is something that really matters for A LOT of people. What is inside the window is a separate thing. And also it's a waste of time for programmers that have to draw decorations to allow basic actions like minimize, close, move a window. Especially that other operating systems don't require it and you have to do it only for wayland.

And I'm fine with external libwayland-decoration.so that will draw decorations on my surfaces. It's just that I will call drawDecorationsOnMySubsurface() instead of requestSSD(). No matter if we will call it "CSD" or whatever. But such library doesn't exist :)

events.target_title: gnome-software / packagekitd 100% CPU usage at startup
XDG-Decoration support

note.body:
The problem is that even if GLFW/SDL/Allegro/etc. would be willing to use GTK (as the mentioned 'toolkit library') for proper client-side decorations, they can't really do it. While GdkGLContext may be usable by these libraries, there's no equivalent Vulkan context interface in GTK3, and the one in GTK4 is pretty limited currently, as it's just a read-only interface for the already created instance and device.

Given the above, and the fact that these low-level libraries obviously don't want to depend on GTK (as they're operating basically on the same level), the "use a toolkit library" path is simply impossible to take in this case.

```
/dev/sda1: LABEL="EFI" UUID="67E3-17ED" TYPE="vfat" PARTLABEL="EFI System Partition" PARTUUID="1eb8278b-ea93-42a9-8411-ef201ed2283b"
```

events.target_title: libmutter: Support top/bottom tiling (for portrait displays and screens with rotation)

note.body:
This feature is very valuable outside of portrait displays: it's also very valuable for large displays, 16:10 displays, 4:3 displays, hi-dpi displays, and when using applications that benefit much more from extra horizontal than vertical space, like terminal emulators tailing logs.

I use a 16:10 (extra vertical space!) hi-dpi display at 150% scaling (extra space all-around!) and with the extra space I very often wish top/bottom tiling, and quarter-tiling, was supported.

events.target_title: Bad shell rendering on 125% fractional scaling

note.body:
I'm having the same experience on Fedora 29 at 150% scaling.

Here are some screenshots from the overview.

Some elements appear to be crisp and properly rendered as if scale-monitor-framebuffer was _not_ enabled:

![Screenshot_from_2018-11-02_21-14-08-6](/uploads/7379d8198b542415e36c82198fb1cc39/Screenshot_from_2018-11-02_21-14-08-6.png)

Some elements are rendered at a low resolution, but with anti-aliasing to smooth them:

![Screenshot_from_2018-11-02_21-14-08-3](/uploads/0bf87ba05d950ce270c728cdb80d0011/Screenshot_from_2018-11-02_21-14-08-3.png)

The rest of the UI elements are low-resolution and not antialiased:

![Screenshot_from_2018-11-02_21-14-08-5](/uploads/952b64da4d85f0e41a154523f31816ce/Screenshot_from_2018-11-02_21-14-08-5.png)

events.target_title: Task Completed time should be in UTC
Let handle recurring task completion by the server
Let handle recurring task completion by the server

note.body:
Evolution v. 3.30.5

The 'duplicate' is a duplicated of the newly created task by outlook. However, with further testing with start & due dates I discovered something else is incorrect:

The duplicate's behaviour changes, and the occurrence count is weird:

I created a task, recurring daily, start & due date 26-02-19 (2 days ago) with 10 occurences. (10 occurrences left)

I completed it, refreshed, and there were two tasks with start & due date 27-02-19. (one 9, one 8 occurrences left)

I completed the one with 9 occurrences left, refreshed, and there were 2 new tasks: one start & due 28-02 (8 occurrences left), One start date 28-02, due date 27-02 (7 occurrences left). 

I completed the task with start & due date 28-02, refreshed, and saw 2 new tasks with start & due date 01-03. (6 and 7 occurrences left)

I completed the task with start 28-02 & due 27-02, refreshed, and saw 2 new tasks: one start 01-03 & due 28-02 (5 occurrences left) and one with start & due 01-03 (6 occurrences left)


So other than the start & due date sometimes acting incorrectly, and the occurrences count being irregular, it is a duplicate.

note: on the website this issue does not happen. I can see all the duplicate tasks, proving this issue is not purely client-side.

Hope this helps!

Nevermind, I have totally mis-identified the issue. I tried to sort on flagged, with the subject flagged mail being part of an email chain. It sorted on flagged within the chain, not within the entire mailbox.

I can confirm flagging on google accounts works as intended, this was just bad testing on my part ;)

note.body:
>  Thanks for a bug report. I'm not sure how evolution would know what to install. Anything can provide org.freedesktop.secrets D-Bus service and I thought that on KDE it's KWallet.

What I learned from a quick google search is that there is `ksecret` which is the project that should provide that dbus API in kde but it's not done and rather inactive. It's not available from the KDE neon apt repos... Don't know why I get the impression that KWallet isn't providing that API...

> You mentioned stderr, does it show any error there, you only do not know what to do from the error message itself, or there is no related error message shown at all?

```
** Message: 21:47:21.918: Remote error from secret service: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown: The name org.freedesktop.secrets was not provided by any .service files
```
is the output. Don't know though if it's stdout or stderr. I just watched the output of flatpak run.

events.target_title: Evolution Flatpak doesn't tell me to install keyring if it's missing

note.body: Hi again, I understand that you want to keep the count of open issues low. I maybe should have explained more. With this issue I wanted you to consider some measure to communicate with the user. Evolution is really hard to work with if there is no secrets provider. It would be nice if Evolution could display an alert message box or something stating that a secrets daemon is missing and that the user should check if the daemon is running. You could also give a hint that they might have to install a provider, that they should look for a package called gnome-keyring. You could also display the string `pkcon install gnome-keyring` so that the user can copy-paste into their terminal.

Network-Manager 1.14.4-2 can't create NAT rules on 4.17.0-3-amd64 - Needs to use iptables-legacy
Network-Manager 1.14.4-2 can't create NAT rules on 4.17.0-3-amd64 - Needs to use iptables-legacy

note.body:
Oops, realized I had the wrong snippet for the fix in there.

This is what network-manager runs:

`/sbin/iptables --table nat --insert POSTROUTING --source 10.201.1.0/255.255.255.0 ! --destination 10.201.1.0/255.255.255.0 --jump MASQUERADE`

which fails with:

`iptables v1.8.1 (nf_tables):  CHAIN_ADD failed (Device or resource busy): chain PREROUTING`


But manually running:

`/usr/sbin/iptables-legacy --table nat --insert POSTROUTING --source 10.201.1.0/255.255.255.0 ! --destination 10.201.1.0/255.255.255.0 --jump MASQUERADE`

works and restores routing.

note.body:
Thanks, the problem is that `HAVE_LIBNOTIFY` is not defined when the package is built.
I checked in the package changelog [1], and recently the build requirement for libnotify was dropped, with the motivation of: 

*follow upstream move of alarm-notify to evolution-data-server.*

I may as well ask to the package maintainer but if you could provide any feedback that's welcome.

[1]: 3.29.2 here https://build.opensuse.org/package/rdiff/openSUSE:Factory/evolution?linkrev=base&rev=217

note.body:
```
[root@entrop-dellpc girepository-1.0]# cd /usr/lib64/girepository-1.0
[root@entrop-dellpc girepository-1.0]# g-ir-generate GLib-2.0.typelib | grep -A 40 spawn_async_with_pipes
[root@entrop-dellpc girepository-1.0]# 

```

that's strange

```
[root@entrop-dellpc girepository-1.0]# ls -l /var/lib/pkg/glib2/*tree /var/lib/pkg/gobject-introspection/*tree
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 52771 ноя  3 16:30 /var/lib/pkg/glib2/glib2-2.58.1.tree
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 20463 окт 25 13:08 /var/lib/pkg/gobject-introspection/gobject-introspection-1.58.0.tree
```

the only flag that was passed to glib2 build was '-D selinux=false' and gobject0introspection was only forced to use cairo with '-Dcairo=true'.

Also:
```
[root@entrop-dellpc gobject-introspection]# grep spawn_async_with_pipes /usr/lib64/libglib-2.0.so
Binary file /usr/lib64/libglib-2.0.so matches
```

events.target_title: nm-openvpn-auth-dialog crashes with gnome-shell

note.body:
I recompiled gobject-introspection rev fdaa3b1a14913c0e54baa98362c88e29691143d0 (latest to 3-30 branch), issue is still present.

How it's built:
```
TANKOSFLAGS+=" -O2 -fPIC"
cd $SOURCE
  mkdir -p build; cd build
  CPPFLAGS=$TANKOSFLAGS \
  CXXFLAGS=$TANKOSFLAGS \
  CFLAGS=$TANKOSFLAGS \
  meson ../ ./  \
    --prefix=/usr \
    --sysconfdir=/etc \
    --mandir=/usr/man \
    --libexecdir=/usr/libexec \
    --libdir=/usr/lib${LIBDIRSUFFIX} \
    --infodir=/usr/info \
    -Dcairo=true
  ninja  || exit 1
  DESTDIR=$PKG ninja install || exit 1
  cd ..
```

Afterwords it's packaged and installed.

events.target_title: nm-openvpn-auth-dialog crashes with gnome-shell

note.body:
Thanks for the hint!

`GPid` wasn't defined in glibconfig.h since it was remade as a wrapper for glibconfig-32.h and glibconfig-64.h which were included at compile time without any problem by all other software I build. I removed the wrapper, recompiled gobject-introspection and now it's working fine.

Many thanks to everyone who helped me to solve this problem.
